<tr>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;vertical-align: top" valign="top">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: separate" width="100%">
<tr>
<td class="editors_note" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding: 0px 40px 16px 40px; border-left: 2px solid #353535; border-right: 2px solid #353535; border-bottom: 2px solid #353535; border-collapse: collapse; border-radius: 0px 0px 10px 10px;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Good morning. </strong>Two rappers released music last week. Well, more accurately, one did and we’re still waiting on the other. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">On Thursday, Kanye West held a listening session for his upcoming album, <em>Donda</em>, in front of a packed house at Atlanta’s football stadium. As the music played, he danced solo in front of his fans without saying a word, then left in under an hour. <em>Donda</em>, which was supposed to be released the next day, hasn’t dropped yet...and reportedly won’t for a few weeks. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Lil Nas X, on the other hand, released his new single with Jack Harlow,  “Industry Baby,” right on time Friday, and also announced he’s raising money for the Bail Project. “I know the pain that incarceration brings to a family. And I know the disproportionate impact that cash bail has on Black Americans,” he wrote.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">At a time when brands are supposed to “obsess” over their customers, Kanye’s indifference feels old-fashioned, while Lil Nas X’s celebration of life in all its forms strikes the right chords. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500">—Neal Freyman</p>
</div>

</tr>

</p>

<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Icebreakers With...Stacy London
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/23/icebreakers-withfashion-icon-now-ceo-stacy-london?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Headshot of Stacy London, CEO of State of Menopause" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODg5L3N0YWN5X2xvbmRvbi5qcGVnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Courtesy of Stacy London</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">From 2003–2013, we gasped along with Stacy London as everyone on <em>What Not to Wear</em> tried to tell her that a sheer, midriff top was appropriate for the office. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Now, London has traded in her reality TV stardom to become the owner and CEO of <a href="https://www.stateofmenopause.com/about/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">State of Menopause</a>, one of only a few health and wellness companies making products for perimenopausal and menopausal consumers. We asked Stacy about her new role and, of course, for some fashion tips. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What was the biggest hurdle in your transition to becoming a business executive? </strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I had talked myself into this idea that I'm “talent.” That's all I do. You know, I'm on television. What do I know about running a company? And I'm like, nobody is born a CEO and an MBA doesn't really mean that much, in my opinion.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>So why’d you do it?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There are zillion things that we don't understand or that we're not taught about menopause. And when I realized what kind of existential toll that took on me, I wanted to take over this company because I wanted to reframe the conversation. I don't think in my entire career there's ever been a time where I was afraid to be vulnerable with my own struggles. And no one was talking about menopause without the sense of fear, shame, confusion, or ignorance. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Where is the best matcha in New York City?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><a href="https://www.nilibk.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Nili</a>. It’s at 360 Smith Street. Also <a href="http://telegraphecafe.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Telegraphe Café</a> on 18th Street between 6th and 7th. Both of them have sweet matcha that's not too sweet.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Are you a breakfast person?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I am. And an every meal person.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Is there an item of clothing or accessory that you think everyone should have in their closet?</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">No. You know, I used to feel that way. And I think the difference between 2003 when <em>What Not to Wear </em>started and now is that we’ve gone away from a “how to” culture where you needed an expert with expertise and 10,000 hours or whatever. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">But we've stopped looking for expertise, and we are looking for shared experience. Wear what you want. But what I really think is that you can wear what you want <em>and</em> get what you want if you understand how style can help you control the narrative of yourself.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>This interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.</em></p>

<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Why Are You <em>Really</em> Looking For a New Job?
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/23/make-work-really-looking-new-job?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Make It Work logo" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em></em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers <a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reader-submitted questions</a> about work in 2021. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>What’s the best way to respond to the interview question, “Why are you looking for new employment” when the answer is “to escape a toxic work environment”?—Casey from Wisconsin</strong></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Hey Casey, if I were asked why I'm looking for a new job and the answer is that I wanted to leave a toxic work environment, I would flip the question and tell the interviewer, "I am looking to be part of a positive and exciting work culture, and I believe that this may be the right place."  </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">I would then explain the specific elements that make up a positive and exciting work culture, whether it’s attentive managers or professional development opportunities. Do some research and be sure to mention how the company you want to work for exemplifies those qualities. In your follow-up email after your interview, emphasize that if you are selected for the role you’ll be a positive contributor to the company’s culture. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Hope it works out!</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Kate </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><em>Something bothering you at work? </em><a href="https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333"><em>Ask Kate here</em></a><em>.</em></p>

<tr>

</a><span> </span>

</a><span> </span>
<a rel="noopener" style="text-decoration: none" target="_blank" href="https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F23%2Fmake-work-really-looking-new-job&title=Make+It+Work%3A+Why+Are+You+Really+Looking+For+a+New+Job%3F&source=www.morningbrew.com&summary=The+question+of+%E2%80%9Cwhy+are+you+looking+for+a+new+job+now%3F%E2%80%9D+is+one+many+hiring+managers+ask+right+out+of+the+gate.+" class=""><img style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; width: 25px" width="25" src="https://media.sailthru.com/5z8/1k5/3/p/605cd9582711b.png">
</a><span> </span>

<td align="left" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 10px 0px; word-break: break-word;">
<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;color: #353535; font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 13px; line-height: 22px; table-layout: auto; width: 100%; border: none;" width="100%">
<tr>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #ffe62e 25%, #0f9046); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
<td style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border: 2px solid #353535; background: white; margin: 0px; padding: 10px;">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;word-break: keep-all; word-wrap: normal; text-align: center; text-transform: uppercase; font-family: Georgia, 'Times New Roman', Times, serif; font-weight: 700; font-size: 16px; line-height: 18px; color: #353535; padding: 0px; margin: 0px;">
ANALYSIS
</p>
</td>
<td width="33%" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt">
<div style="text-align: center; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;">
 
</div>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</td>
</tr>
<tr class="">
<td class="column" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;">
<div style="font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;">
<h1 style="margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left">
Is Everyone at the Olympics Pretending It’s 2020?
</h1>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/23/olympics-may-rescheduled-2020-logo-doesnt-know?utm_source=morning_brew" style="text-decoration:none; border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="TOKYO, JAPAN - 2021/06/25: People wearing masks as a preventive measure" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODk5L3Blb3BsZV93ZWFyaW5nX21hc2tzLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;">
<small>
<em>Sopa Images/Getty Images</em>
</small>
</p>
</a>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">There's a lot that feels "off" about this year's Olympics. Here's one of them: Despite the fact that it is very much the year 2021, all Olympic marketing materials, from the TV ads to the gold medals, are stamped with the “Tokyo 2020” logo.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">It’s not a mistake. A decision to keep the original branding was made last March, when Japan and the International Olympic Committee agreed to postpone the Summer games for the first time in history.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Why not just change it to the correct year?</strong> Officials explained that Olympic years are always even numbers. It's a tradition, like a skyscraper skipping the 13th floor or the youngest sibling having a meltdown on any family vacation. In an interview last year Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike said, “An odd number is out of the question.”</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Wow. We have chills. Also, not buying it. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">The real reason Tokyo 2020 didn’t become Tokyo 2021 is because a change would have been supremely expensive. Organizers spent $1.3 billion making billboards, giant public countdown clocks, and commercials with the original logo. Some sponsors in Japan have been creating merchandise and promotional materials for the Games since 2015. This isn’t something a little Wite-Out and a Sharpie can fix. </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">And even if the Olympics did decide to update the branding to reflect the correct year, it would have to make sure everyone involved got the memo. Branding inconsistencies would give the same vibes as a high school winter formal: Is the theme Under the Sea or A Night to Remember? </p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Another argument against changing the name is IP. The Olympics have some of the most intense copyright protections in the game, but there is nothing strong enough to keep cool dudes with pencil mustaches from an ironic t-shirt—and what’s more ironic than a tee for an Olympics that never happened? One can only imagine the underground market that would have erupted for knock-off “Tokyo 2020” merch. </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1">
<span>After all, you can still </span><span><a href="https://www.ebay.com/itm/333782759681?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">buy</a></span><span> shirts from the 2012 New York City Marathon that was canceled after Hurricane Sandy. </span>
</li>
<li aria-level="1">
<span>Same with the delayed </span><span><a href="https://www.horseracingnation.com/news/May_2_branded_Kentucky_Derby_merch_on_sale_with_charitable_twist_123?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">2020 Kentucky Derby</a></span><span> or last year’s postponed </span><span><a href="https://www.fanatics.com/?query=2020%20march%20madness" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">NCAA tournament</a></span><span>.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><strong>Bottom line: </strong>For all these reasons, marketing experts say organizers made the right call in keeping 2020 in the name. And let’s be honest—with Covid-19 cases rising, no fans in attendance, and strict social distancing rules in place, it does fit the mood.</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse" width="100%">

Open House
</h1>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">Welcome to Open House, the only newsletter section that makes you go, “Wait—<em>how</em> much?” We’ll give you a few facts about a listing and you try to guess the price.</p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81OTAyL2FybGluZ3Rvbl92aXJnaW5pYV9ob3VzZS5wbmciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24ifQ==" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="White house on corner lot in Arlington, Virginia" data-source="Bright MLS" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Bright MLS</em> </small></p>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">We know what you’re thinking: “Only one photo? Where’s the collage?” But the beauty of this 5,227 square-foot <a href="https://www.zillow.com/homedetails/1630-N-Barton-St-Arlington-VA-22201/12078882_zpid/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">lot</a> in Arlington, VA, is in its simplicity. Along with being a short Uber ride to Washington, DC, amenities include: </p>
<ul style="line-height:22px">
<li aria-level="1"><span>Attached garage with one parking space</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Big trees</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Water heater (not new, just one in general)</span></li>
<li aria-level="1"><span>Great location to build on if you’re cool with bulldozing the home</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px">How much for the world’s most average house? Scroll to the bottom of the newsletter to find out.</p>

#353535;\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eTwo rappers released music last week. Well, more accurately, one did and we’re still waiting on the other. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eOn Thursday, Kanye West held a listening session for his upcoming album, \u003cem\u003eDonda\u003c/em\u003e, in front of a packed house at Atlanta’s football stadium. As the music played, he danced solo in front of his fans without saying a word, then left in under an hour. \u003cem\u003eDonda\u003c/em\u003e, which was supposed to be released the next day, hasn’t dropped yet...and reportedly won’t for a few weeks. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eLil Nas X, on the other hand, released his new single with Jack Harlow,  “Industry Baby,” right on time Friday, and also announced he’s raising money for the Bail Project. “I know the pain that incarceration brings to a family. And I know the disproportionate impact that cash bail has on Black Americans,” he wrote.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAt a time when brands are supposed to “obsess” over their customers, Kanye’s indifference feels old-fashioned, while Lil Nas X’s celebration of life in all its forms strikes the right chords. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;font-family:flood-std, Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;font-size:16px;font-weight:500\"\u003e—Neal Freyman\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE --\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd align=\"left\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nIcebreakers With...Stacy London\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/23/icebreakers-withfashion-icon-now-ceo-stacy-london?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Headshot of Stacy London, CEO of State of Menopause\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODg5L3N0YWN5X2xvbmRvbi5qcGVnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eCourtesy of Stacy London\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eFrom 2003–2013, we gasped along with Stacy London as everyone on \u003cem\u003eWhat Not to Wear\u003c/em\u003e tried to tell her that a sheer, midriff top was appropriate for the office. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNow, London has traded in her reality TV stardom to become the owner and CEO of \u003ca href=\"https://www.stateofmenopause.com/about/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eState of Menopause\u003c/a\u003e, one of only a few health and wellness companies making products for perimenopausal and menopausal consumers. We asked Stacy about her new role and, of course, for some fashion tips. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat was the biggest hurdle in your transition to becoming a business executive? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI had talked myself into this idea that I'm “talent.” That's all I do. You know, I'm on television. What do I know about running a company? And I'm like, nobody is born a CEO and an MBA doesn't really mean that much, in my opinion.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSo why’d you do it?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere are zillion things that we don't understand or that we're not taught about menopause. And when I realized what kind of existential toll that took on me, I wanted to take over this company because I wanted to reframe the conversation. I don't think in my entire career there's ever been a time where I was afraid to be vulnerable with my own struggles. And no one was talking about menopause without the sense of fear, shame, confusion, or ignorance. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhere is the best matcha in New York City?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nilibk.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNili\u003c/a\u003e. It’s at 360 Smith Street. Also \u003ca href=\"http://telegraphecafe.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eTelegraphe Café\u003c/a\u003e on 18th Street between 6th and 7th. Both of them have sweet matcha that's not too sweet.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAre you a breakfast person?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI am. And an every meal person.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIs there an item of clothing or accessory that you think everyone should have in their closet?\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eNo. You know, I used to feel that way. And I think the difference between 2003 when \u003cem\u003eWhat Not to Wear \u003c/em\u003estarted and now is that we’ve gone away from a “how to” culture where you needed an expert with expertise and 10,000 hours or whatever. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eBut we've stopped looking for expertise, and we are looking for shared experience. Wear what you want. But what I really think is that you can wear what you want \u003cem\u003eand\u003c/em\u003e get what you want if you understand how style can help you control the narrative of yourself.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis interview has been lightly edited and condensed for clarity.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F23%2Ficebreakers-withfashion-icon-now-ceo-stacy-london\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nWhy Are You \u003cem\u003eReally\u003c/em\u003e Looking For a New Job?\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/23/make-work-really-looking-new-job?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Make It Work logo\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC80Njg5L21ha2VfaXRfd29ya19sb2dvLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eEach week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers \u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereader-submitted questions\u003c/a\u003e about work in 2021. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat’s the best way to respond to the interview question, “Why are you looking for new employment” when the answer is “to escape a toxic work environment”?—Casey from Wisconsin\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHey Casey, if I were asked why I'm looking for a new job and the answer is that I wanted to leave a toxic work environment, I would flip the question and tell the interviewer, \"I am looking to be part of a positive and exciting work culture, and I believe that this may be the right place.\"  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eI would then explain the specific elements that make up a positive and exciting work culture, whether it’s attentive managers or professional development opportunities. Do some research and be sure to mention how the company you want to work for exemplifies those qualities. In your follow-up email after your interview, emphasize that if you are selected for the role you’ll be a positive contributor to the company’s culture. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eHope it works out!\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eKate \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSomething bothering you at work? \u003c/em\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://link.morningbrew.com/click/23923023.14227/aHR0cHM6Ly9tb3JuaW5nYnJld2RhaWx5LnR5cGVmb3JtLmNvbS90by9mWTFDR3p5WT91dG1fc291cmNlPW1vcm5pbmdfYnJldw/5c881db32ddf9c27c11a8f77B1c068d44?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eAsk Kate here\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cem\u003e.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F23%2Fmake-work-really-looking-new-job\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block; background: linear-gradient(90deg, #2b9295, #1c7ff2); background-color: #1c7ff2; line-height: 4px; font-size: 4px; width: 100%; margin: 20px 0;\"\u003e\n \n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003ctr class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003ctd class=\"column\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;font-size: 0px; padding: 25px; word-break: break-word;\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv style=\"font-size: 16px; font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; line-height: 16px; text-align: left; color: #353535;\"\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"margin-top:0px;font-family:Georgia;font-size:24px;font-style:normal;font-weight:700;line-height:34px;letter-spacing:0em;text-align:left\"\u003e\nIs Everyone at the Olympics Pretending It’s 2020?\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/07/23/olympics-may-rescheduled-2020-logo-doesnt-know?utm_source=morning_brew\" style=\"text-decoration:none; border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"TOKYO, JAPAN - 2021/06/25: People wearing masks as a preventive measure\" style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC81ODk5L3Blb3BsZV93ZWFyaW5nX21hc2tzLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:16px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eSopa Images/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThere's a lot that feels \"off\" about this year's Olympics. Here's one of them: Despite the fact that it is very much the year 2021, all Olympic marketing materials, from the TV ads to the gold medals, are stamped with the “Tokyo 2020” logo.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eIt’s not a mistake. A decision to keep the original branding was made last March, when Japan and the International Olympic Committee agreed to postpone the Summer games for the first time in history.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhy not just change it to the correct year?\u003c/strong\u003e Officials explained that Olympic years are always even numbers. It's a tradition, like a skyscraper skipping the 13th floor or the youngest sibling having a meltdown on any family vacation. In an interview last year Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike said, “An odd number is out of the question.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eWow. We have chills. Also, not buying it. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eThe real reason Tokyo 2020 didn’t become Tokyo 2021 is because a change would have been supremely expensive. Organizers spent $1.3 billion making billboards, giant public countdown clocks, and commercials with the original logo. Some sponsors in Japan have been creating merchandise and promotional materials for the Games since 2015. This isn’t something a little Wite-Out and a Sharpie can fix. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnd even if the Olympics did decide to update the branding to reflect the correct year, it would have to make sure everyone involved got the memo. Branding inconsistencies would give the same vibes as a high school winter formal: Is the theme Under the Sea or A Night to Remember? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003eAnother argument against changing the name is IP. The Olympics have some of the most intense copyright protections in the game, but there is nothing strong enough to keep cool dudes with pencil mustaches from an ironic t-shirt—and what’s more ironic than a tee for an Olympics that never happened? One can only imagine the underground market that would have erupted for knock-off “Tokyo 2020” merch. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"line-height:22px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAfter all, you can still \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.ebay.com/itm/333782759681?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebuy\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e shirts from the 2012 New York City Marathon that was canceled after Hurricane Sandy. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli aria-level=\"1\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eSame with the delayed \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.horseracingnation.com/news/May_2_branded_Kentucky_Derby_merch_on_sale_with_charitable_twist_123?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e2020 Kentucky Derby\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e or last year’s postponed \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.fanatics.com/?query=2020%20march%20madness\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNCAA tournament\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"display:block;margin:13px 0;line-height:22px\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eFor all these reasons, marketing experts say organizers made the right call in keeping 2020 in the name. And let’s be honest—with Covid-19 cases rising, no fans in attendance, and strict social distancing rules in place, it does fit the mood.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable border=\"0\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;border-collapse: collapse\" width=\"100%\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"border-collapse:collapse;mso-table-lspace:0pt;mso-table-rspace:0pt;padding-top: 12px\"\u003e\n\u003ca rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2021%2F07%2F23%2Folympics-may-rescheduled-2020-logo-doesnt-know\" class=\"\"\u003e\u003cimg style=\"border:0;height:auto;line-height:100%;outline:none;text-decoration:none;-ms-interpolation-mode:bicubic;display: inline-block;
